The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a branch of the World Health Organization, classifies processed red meat as "carcinogenic to humans" (Group 1) and red meat in general as "probably carcinogenic to humans" (Group 2A). This classification is based on strong evidence from numerous epidemiological studies showing positive associations between high red meat intake and increased risks of colorectal cancer, pancreatic cancer, and prostate cancer.

A 2015 meta-analysis of 25 prospective studies found that high consumption of red meat, especially processed meat, was associated with a significantly increased risk of colorectal cancer. The risk increased by 17% per 100 g/day of red meat and by 18% per 50 g/day of processed meat.

The American Cancer Society and the American Institute for Cancer Research both recommend limiting red meat intake and avoiding processed meats to reduce cancer risk. The World Cancer Research Fund International states that there is "strong evidence" that consuming red meat and processed meat are both causes of colorectal cancer.

However, it is important to note that the absolute risk increase is relatively small. A 2019 analysis estimated that for every 1,000 people who eat the equivalent of one hot dog per day over 10 years, 40 more people would develop colon cancer than if they ate no processed meat at all.

Some studies suggest that the methods used to cook red meat, such as grilling or frying at high temperatures, may produce carcinogenic compounds like heterocyclic amines (HCAs) and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) that could contribute to cancer risk.

It is also worth noting that not all studies have found a significant association between red meat intake and cancer. Some have even suggested a protective effect of red meat on certain cancer types. However, these findings are in the minority.

In summary, while there is strong evidence from epidemiological studies and expert consensus that high red meat consumption, particularly of processed meats, is associated with an increased risk of certain cancers like colorectal cancer, the absolute risk increase is relatively modest. More research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms behind this association and to determine if there are any potential beneficial effects of moderate red meat intake.
